t: Proverbs 14
The*pn wisest of women builds her house, but*ld folly with her own hands tears it down.
Whoever*ln walks in uprightness fears the Lord,*s but*ld he who is devious in his ways despises him.
By*ln the mouth of a fool comes a rod for his back, but*ld the lips of the wise will preserve them.
Where*ln there are no oxen, the manger is clean, but*ld abundant crops come by the strength of the ox.
A*ln faithful witness does not lie, but*ld a false witness breathes out lies.
A*ln scoffer seeks wisdom in vain, but*ld knowledge is easy for a man of understanding.
Leave*ln the presence of a fool, for*ld there you do not meet words of knowledge.
The*ln wisdom of the prudent is to discern his way, but*ld the folly of fools is deceiving.
Fools*ln mock at the guilt offering, but*ld the upright enjoy acceptance.
The*ln heart knows its own bitterness, and*ld no stranger shares its joy.
The*ln house of the wicked will be destroyed, but*ld the tent of the upright will flourish.
There*ln is a way that seems right to a man, but*ld its end is the way to death.
Even*ln in laughter the heart may ache, and*ld the end of joy may be grief.
The*ln backslider in heart will be filled with the fruit of his ways, and*ld a good man will be filled with the fruit of his ways.
The*ln simple believes everything, but*ld the prudent gives thought to his steps.
One*ln who is wise is cautious and turns away from evil, but*ld a fool is reckless and careless.
A*ln man of quick temper acts foolishly, and*ld a man of evil devices is hated.
The*ln simple inherit folly, but*ld the prudent are crowned with knowledge.
The*ln evil bow down before the good, the*ld wicked at the gates of the righteous.
The*ln poor is disliked even by his neighbor, but*ld the rich has many friends.
Whoever*ln despises his neighbor is a sinner, but*ld blessed is he who is generous to the poor.
Do*ln they not go astray who devise evil? Those*ld who devise good meet steadfast love and faithfulness.
In*ln all toil there is profit, but*ld mere talk tends only to poverty.
The*ln crown of the wise is their wealth, but*ld the folly of fools brings folly.
A*ln truthful witness saves lives, but*ld one who breathes out lies is deceitful.
In*ln the fear of the Lord*s one has strong confidence, and*ld his children will have a refuge.
The*ln fear of the Lord*s is a fountain of life, that*ld one may turn away from the snares of death.
In*ln a multitude of people is the glory of a king, but*ld without people a prince is ruined.
Whoever*ln is slow to anger has great understanding, but*ld he who has a hasty temper exalts folly.
A*ln tranquil heart gives life to the flesh, but*ld envy makes the bones rot.
Whoever*ln oppresses a poor man insults his Maker, but*ld he who is generous to the needy honors him.
The*ln wicked is overthrown through his evildoing, but*ld the righteous finds refuge in his death.
Wisdom*ln rests in the heart of a man of understanding, but*ld it makes itself known even in the midst of fools.
Righteousness*ln exalts a nation, but*ld sin is a reproach to any people.
A*ln servant who deals wisely has the kingâ€™s favor, but*ld his wrath falls on one who acts shamefully.
